descriptions.abande: Abande is the second game in Dieter Stein's stacking trilogy. Place or move pieces and stacks to generate the highest score you can whilst always keeping the board connected. The square, snubsquare, and hex boards are available.
descriptions.accasta: Accasta is the first of Dieter Stein's stacking trilogy. The goal is to get three of your own stacks into the enemy's castle area. There are three different types of pieces in the base version. In the "Pari" variant, movement is determined by how many friendly pieces are in the stack.
descriptions.acity: Alien City is a combination Piecepack/Icehouse game about building a city on a newly colonized world. Four guilds compete for customers, and the player has to predict which bets are going to pay off. Each turn, the player places either a tower or dome and may optionally claim a tower they think is going to score big when the game ends. Play continues until no more construction is possible. Scores are based on the relative positions of buildings to claimed towers.
descriptions.agere: A connection game where you can also stack pieces. Played either on a triangle board where you try to connect all three sides, or a circular "cobweb" board where you connect opposite sides.
descriptions.almatafl: AlmaTafl is an asymmetrical game where one side plays the defenders trying to get the king to safety, while the other side tries to capture the king or render him defenseless.
descriptions.amazons: A two-player game played on a 10x10 board. Each player has four queens (the eponymous amazons). Each turn, you move one of the queens and then shoot an arrow from your final square. The arrow causes that square to become blocked for the rest of the game. Queens and arrows cannot cross blocked squares or squares occupied by other queens. The winner is the last person who is able to move.
descriptions.archimedes: A game based on the legend of Archimedes teaching the Syracuse soldiers how to focus the sun's rays with their shields to set ships on fire. The goal is to begin your turn with a piece in your enemy's port. At the end of each turn, any enemy ships in sight of three of your pieces are destroyed by fire. Destroyed ships can eventually be rebuilt.
descriptions.armadas: A miniatures-style game played with Looney pyramids where you captain a fleet of ships on the open seas, trying to sink all who stand against you.
descriptions.atoll: Atoll is a generalisation of Hex where you have to connect two islands of your colour on opposite sides of the board with a contiguous chain of stones of your colour. The islands themselves can be part of the chain. So, for example, you could form one bridge between your north and west islands and a second bridge between your west and south islands to win.
descriptions.attangle: Attangle is the final entry in Dieter Stein's stacking trilogy. Place and move pieces to build stacks. First person to build three triple stacks wins. The "Grand Attangle" variant is also implemented.
descriptions.bao: A traditional mancala-style sowing game from East Africa where you attempt to eliminate all pieces from the opposing front row or leave them with no legal moves.
descriptions.bide: Up to six players take turns placing pieces on the board, pushing adjacent pieces outward. One can also pass to build up a number of pieces that can be placed at once later. Pieces closer to the centre are more valuable. Highest-scoring group wins!
descriptions.binar: An "in-a-row" game where the rows (and possibly columns) are treated as binary numbers. Create a line of four "1"s on your turn to win.
descriptions.blam: An Icehouse game for 2–4 players played on a standard chess board. Pieces placed push adjacent pieces away. Push pieces off the board to capture them. Whoever has captured the highest pip total of pieces at the end of the game wins.
descriptions.blockade: Blockade (also known as Cul-de-sac) is a 'beat the barrier' game where you get one of your pawns to a starting space of your opponent. Players place 2-wide walls to block each other.
descriptions.blooms: Each player owns 2 colours of stones. Players take turns placing one or two stones each turn (if you place two, they must be different colours), then capture all fenced enemy blooms. The first player to capture a certain number of stones wins.
descriptions.boom: A minimalist abstract that combines simple move and capture mechanics with a scoring mechanic. Score by bearing your stacks off the opposing side of the board, but you'll want to reduce your opponent's scoring opportunities at the same time.
descriptions.bounce: Manoeuvre your disconnected checkers into a single, orthogonally connected whole.
descriptions.breakthrough: One of the simplest "get to your opponent's home row" games around. Pieces move and capture like chess pawns. First to the other home row wins. Also includes a "Bombardment" variant where instead of regular capture moves, one can detonate a piece, which destroys it and all pieces around it.
descriptions.byte: Manoeuvre and merge stacks of checkers while attempting to be the one on top when the stack reaches a certain height.
descriptions.cannon: A two-player game played on a 10x10 board. Soldiers can move independently, but three soldiers in a row form a "cannon" and can move along their length or kill soldiers two or three spaces away. The first player to capture the opposing town wins.
descriptions.catchup: Catchup is a simple abstract game with a devilish dynamic. The goal is to have the largest group of stones on the board when the board is full of stones, but as you get closer to winning, your opponent gets more powerful. Whereas most stone-placement games are about position, Catchup is about timing, position, and the interplay between them.
descriptions.ccorridor: In Cairo Corridor players alternate turns placing their pentagonal pieces, on a board with a Cairo pentagonal tiling. Eventually there will be only one 'path' of empty spaces which connects the 4 sides. Players score points based on how many tiles are adjacent to that path. In the event of a tie, the player that placed the last tile before the game ends loses.
descriptions.ceph: A two-player game of area control by capture using dice. The goal is to fill a board with as many of your dice as possible. This is complicated by a capturing mechanic that keeps the board in constant flux. The game ends when the board has been completely filled. Draws are not possible.
descriptions.chase: Chase is a unique move and capture game played on a cylindrical hex board with dice. Pieces move the exact number of spaces showing on the die face (its "speed"). Landing on enemy pieces captures them; landing on friendly pieces bumps them, which can cause chain reactions. The chamber in the centre of the board is a way of gaining more pieces. You must maintain a total of 25 speed throughout the game. Once you are no longer able to do that, you lose.
descriptions.clearcut: Connect opposite sides of the board. Lines of pieces may cross in some circumstances, and this results in the removal of some opposing pieces.
descriptions.clusterfuss: Continually capture pieces with the aim of detaching (and thereby eliminating) groups of opposing pieces. Be the last man standing!
descriptions.complica: A simple connect-4 game played on a narrow field where the columns never fill up.
descriptions.conhex: In ConHex, the winner is the first player to connect their assigned sides of a square board. The board is a pattern of non-regular hexagons with a few non-hexagonal polygons. Players alternate turns placing pieces of their own color on a vertex, and a player can claim a space after placing pieces on at least half the vertices of that space.
descriptions.connect6: Players take turns placing two stones of their colour to try to get a six (or more) in a row. In the default opening, the first player places one stone in the middle of the board. The game ends in a draw if no player gets a six-in-a-row or on two consecutive passes.
descriptions.connecticut: Connecticut is a connection game where you win by connecting your edges with a chain of orthogonally or diagonally adjacent stones. On your move, you either place a single stone or a 1x3 triomino (three stones in an unbroken line). The first move must be a single stone, and the pie rule applies.
descriptions.courtesan: Get your king to the other side of the board while safely "hiding" it among your other pieces.
descriptions.crossway: A game of connecting opposite sides of the board, but lines of pieces may not cross each other.
descriptions.dagnacht: An n-in-a-row game on a checkered board. You can only place pieces on the dark squares, but you can then move pieces onto the light squares. Win by getting 5 in a row orthogonally (including 3 light squares if you are player 1) or 4 in a row on a light diagonal. Winner of the Abstract Games magazine's 2021 "Unequal Board Spaces Game Design Competition".
descriptions.dameo: A modern draughts game with linear movement and orthogonal captures.
descriptions.diffusion: Diffusion is a modern mancala-style game where the goal is to empty out your own pits.
descriptions.dipole: An anti-race game where you inexorably lose pieces, but you try to be the last one to run out.
descriptions.entropy: Entropy is a 2-player game representing the struggle between Order and Chaos. The Order player tries to organize their board in such a way to score the highest amount. But the Chaos player gets to *place* the pieces and attempts to thwart Order whenever possible.
descriptions.epam: Epaminondas is an elegant 2-player game in which you try to overwhelm your opponent's home row. Pieces move as phalanxes a number of spaces up to their length. The rules are exceedingly simple, but the result is something deep and complex.
descriptions.exxit: Exxit is fundamentally an area control game. Manoeuvre your pieces to create new tiles. Fight to create the largest connected island of tiles of your colour. The game board is built out as you play.
descriptions.fabrik: In Fabrik, players manipulate workers to determine where pieces can be placed. The goal is to get a certain number of your pieces in a row. In the default game, players can move either worker. The "Arbeiter" variant gives each player control over a specific worker.
descriptions.fanorona: Fanorona is the national game of Madagascar, and it is believed to have been derived from the game of Alquerque. Checkers can move to adjacent empty spaces and capture opposing pieces by approach or withdrawal. As long as you can keep capturing, you may continue to move. Continue until you capture all your opponent's pieces!
descriptions.fendo: In Fendo, players manoeuvre their pieces to build fences, eventually creating closed off areas that hopefully only they control. Once all the pieces are isolated, the player who controls the most area wins.
descriptions.fightopia: A "get to your opponent's home row" game where you have three different sizes of pieces. Each moves and captures differently.
descriptions.flume: Place stones to make connections. Connecting to three or four other pieces allows you to place another stone. When the board is full, the player with the most stones on the board wins.
descriptions.fnap: A tile laying game where players simultaneously select the tile they will play, but only one player gets to place them both. Points are scored by dominating rows and columns and by creating groups of connected (and disconnected) tiles.
descriptions.focus: A Sid Sackon classic. One may move stacks of pieces as many spaces as pieces in the stack. Once stacks become higher than 5 pieces, the bottom-most pieces are captured. The last person able to move a stack wins.
descriptions.four: A game in which four shapes in four colours are placed in a virtual grid according to four constraints. Be the last player able to place.
descriptions.fourinarow: A simple game of getting four (or more) in a row with the twist: there is gravity.
descriptions.furl: Either furl up a row of your discs, or unfurl a stack. If you have a disc in your end row at the start of your turn, you win.
descriptions.garden: Two wizards share a garden plot and try to harvest valuable reagents. Both are sharing the same pool of seeds. Planting a seed changes the plants around it. Form four in a row to harvest. Most harvests wins!
descriptions.gess: In Gess, the 'pieces' are 3×3 patterns stones. A player can use any 3×3 portion of the board that contains at least one of their stones and none of their opponent's stones. If a 3x3 piece moves in such a way that it overlaps one or more stones (of either player), all stones that the piece moves onto are captured. Each player must maintain one piece that is a ring of eight stones around an empty square at all times. If one player is in a position where they no longer have such a ring anywhere on the board for any reason, they lose.
descriptions.gomoku: A classic game where you try to get exactly five stones in a row. Six in a row does not count as a win. The game ends in a draw if no player gets a five-in-a-row or on two consecutive passes.
descriptions.halfcut: Connect opposite sides of the board. Lines of pieces may cross in some circumstances, and this results in the removal of some opposing pieces.
descriptions.havannah: A connection game where you vye to form either a ring, a bridge, or a fork. A ring is a chain around at least one cell. A bridge is a chain linking two corners. A fork is a chain linking three sides. Corners do not belong to either side.
descriptions.hens: Hens and Chicks is a draughts-style game with two types of pieces and a unique capturing mechanic. The winner is the first to land a piece in their opponent's home row or to eliminate all the opposing hens.
descriptions.hex: In Hex, two players attempt to connect opposite sides of a rhombus-shaped board made of hexagonal cells
descriptions.hexy: An adaptation of Y on a regular hexagon where players vye to control most of the perimeter of the board.
descriptions.homeworlds: An Icehouse game for 2 to 4 players. Players are interstellar civilizations vying for dominance. Each of the four colours of pyramid gives access to different actions. Amass a fleet, explore the galaxy, and ultimately destroy your opponent.
descriptions.iqishiqi: Iqishiqi (pronounced EE-chee-shee-chee) is an abstract strategy game that is played on a hexagonal board composed of hexagonal cells. Players own designated edges of the board, and by clever placement of stones they push a neutral stone around the board. A player wins if he/she moves the neutral stone to one of his/her edges, or leaves his/her opponent unable to move.
descriptions.irensei: Irensei is a mixture of Go and Gomoku. Get a seven in a row inside the middle 15x15 region of the Go board to win. To reduce the first player's advantage, the first player loses if they make an overline (even if it extends beyond the 15x15 region), but the second player may win by overline.
descriptions.lielow: A wartime tale of Machiavellian usurpership. You win if your piece lands on your opponent's king. You also win if your opponent chooses to move their king off the board.
descriptions.loa: A classic game where you try to gather all your pieces into a single connected group. Pieces can only move the exact number of spaces as the number of pieces that lie along the line of movement. The "Scrambled Eggs" initial layout variant is supported.
descriptions.manalath: Manalath is a game on a hexagonal grid where you can place pieces of either colour. You win if at the end of your turn there's a group of five pieces of your colour, but you *lose* if there's a group of four stones of your colour. How are you going to do that?!
descriptions.mattock: In Mattock, you play miners digging corridors through the rock. You can't dig too closely together though, or the mine will collapse. To win, trap your opponent so they run out of space to mine.
descriptions.mchess: A Looney pyramid game for two players played on half of a standard chess board. It is a chess-like strategy game in which location, rather than piece color, determines which pieces you may move. Like Chess, each type of piece has its own way of moving, and you capture by moving onto an opponent's square; but unlike Chess, you can only move pieces sitting in your own quadrant, and only attack those in other quadrants, which may include your own former pieces. The game ends when someone runs out of pieces, and the winner is the player who captured the most points.
descriptions.meridians: Meridians is a territorial game with the goal of annihilating the opponent's stones. Starting with an empty board, players alternate turns placing a stone on an empty point as in Go. Groups should be "seen" by other friendly stone through a straight path or they will be removed on your opponent's turn.
descriptions.mimic: A game where enemy pieces mimic your moves while you race to be the first player to reach the back row.
descriptions.mirador: Mirador is a fast and exhilerating connection game played on a 27 x 27 square grid by placing 2 x 2 squares to represent watchtowers. It uses line-of-sight connections and equivalent goals (making it more of a race than a pure connection game).
descriptions.monkey: You start with a single queen, composed of a stack of checkers. When you make noncapturing moves, the queen leaves a singleton behind. Queens and singletons move and capture like chess queens. To win, capture the opposing queen or leave them with no legal moves.
descriptions.murus: Murus Gallicus is a two-player breakthrough game in which players try to create impenetrable walls of stone as menacing formations approach, reminiscent of Julius Caesar's Gallic Wars.
descriptions.mvolcano: An Icehouse puzzle game for 2 players. Stacks of pyramids are volcanos, some of which are capped. As you move caps around, you cause eruptions that may lead to you capturing pieces. This is an older version of the game. It is played on a 6x6 board, and the game ends as soon as someone captures at least one piece of each colour or all three white pieces. Scores are then calculated. Highest score wins.
descriptions.mixtour: Two players create towers with the goal of creating a tower at least five high with your colour at the top. The twist here is two-fold: (1) you can move opponent's pieces and (2) movement range is determined by the *target* stack height and not the moving stack height.
descriptions.nex: Nex (or Neutral Hex) is a variant of the Hex connection game where there are neutral pieces. On your turn, you may either (1) place a piece of your colour and a neutral colour on an empty space, or (2) swap two neutral pieces to your colour and one of your piece to the neutral colour.
descriptions.onager: In Onager each player tries to reach the opponent's back rank. Onager is named after a Roman siege engine that is a type of catapult, as the way the pieces move resembles how projectiles are hurled forward with this device.
descriptions.orb: Generatorb is 2-player game played on a standard chess board. Players start in opposite corners and attempt to reach their opponent's generator core or occupy the majority of cells on the front line. During play, you can stack up to three checkers in a space. Stacks of different heights behave differently, leading to engaging strategic options.
descriptions.ordo: Ordo is a "get to your opponent's home row" game in which you must always keep your pieces connected. Pieces can move singly and also as a group in certain situations. You can also win by breaking up your opponent's group in such a way that they can't reconnect it.
descriptions.pente: In Pente, players take turns placing stones on the intersections of the board. The first player to get five in a row or capture ten stones wins.
descriptions.pigs: Robo Battle Pigs is a game of robot combat where you program a series of moves in an attempt to destroy all opposing pigs. This implementation supports 2–4 players.
descriptions.phutball: Phutball (short for philosopher's football) is a classic two-player soccer-esque board game of shared pieces where you attempt to get the ball across your opponent's goal line.
descriptions.pikemen:
A Looney pyramid game where the pyramids represents soldiers with long pikes. Pieces charge in the direction they're facing and can then change their orientation. Capture a certain number of enemy soldiers to win.

While the game is technically playable by three and four players, this implementation only supports two players.
descriptions.quagmire: A race to stay afloat as the land gives away underfoot. Walk, run, and jump around the board to hamper the other team, but make sure to leave enough room for your own!
descriptions.quax: Quax is a connection game on a square board with a special move: instead of placing a stone, you may connect diagonally adjacent stones.
descriptions.queensland: Create long open corridors between your pieces to score points. Easy, right?
descriptions.razzle: Razzle Dazzle, also called Knight Moves, is a fast-paced game, designed to recreate as much of the experience of Ultimate Frisbee as possible while keeping the rules and gameplay simple and elegant. Two players try to move their ball to the opposite side of the board, using their 5 pieces as passing instruments. A player may either pass the ball or move a piece like a knight in a game of Chess.
descriptions.realm: Realm is played on a unique 12x12 board with only two types of mobile pieces. The goal is to capture more territory than your opponent by blocking and immobilizing their pieces. A few simple rules let you generate more pieces, which leads to ever-evolving tactics.
descriptions.renju: An asymmetric five-in-a-row game where the first player is not allowed to create double open threes, double fours, or overlines. Competitive openings like Taraguchi-10 and Soosõrv-8 are implemented here.
descriptions.reversi: Reversi is a classic game where you try to capture your opponent's pieces by sandwiching them between your own.
descriptions.rootbound: In Root Bound, two players’ plants vie for control of the space at the sides of a planter as the room for new growth rapidly dwindles.
descriptions.saltire: Saltire is a connection game where on your turn, you may place a stone of your color on an empty point or swap two orthogonally or diagonally adjacent stones. A crosscut is a 2×2 area containing two diagonally adjacent black stones and two diagonally adjacent white stones. A supercut is a crosscut along with eight additional stones orthogonally adjacent to like-colored stones in the crosscut. A swap must decrease either the number of crosscuts or the number of supercuts on the board, and it must not increase the number of crosscuts.
descriptions.scaffold: Scaffold is a drawless connection game played on the intersections of a square grid using stones (as in Go). Black is trying to connect N-S edges of the board, White E-W with an orthogonally connected group. On your turn, place a stone of your color on an empty point. Then, if possible, place a stone of your color on an empty point that is orthogonally adjacent to two groups of your color, and keep making such placements until no more are possible.
descriptions.slither: Square-board connection game with updated rules from 2018. Optionally move a piece and then place a piece, such that no two pieces of a colour are diagonally adjacent to each other unless they are orthogonally connected by a like-coloured stone. In Advanced Slither, a piece may only move if it is part of a contiguous orthogonal group consisting of pieces of both colours.
descriptions.streetcar: It's against the law to build housing or transit in this wealthy neighborhood. Remove single-family housing limits to let citizens build, making the neighborhood more affordable and diverse. Then connect new buildings with streetcar lines of your own color to score points.
descriptions.strings: Players simultaneously choose a string to pull, moving, splitting, and joining stacks of coins. The winner is the first one able to get five coins on their home spaces. Are you pulling strings? Or is your opponent pulling yours?
descriptions.symple: A territory game where you get a point for every stone placed, and a penalty for each individual group of connected pieces. Find the right balance to maximize your score.
descriptions.tablero: A quick-playing dice game where players compete to control high-value spaces on the board.
descriptions.taiji: Two players take turns placing one piece of each colour next to each other. The winner is the one who forms the largest orthogonal groups of their own colour.
descriptions.take: Grow root-like formations of stones from seeds. Plants die when they run out of room to grow. The winner is the last player with a plant alive on the board.
descriptions.tbt: A simple dice game where you attempt to form stacks of equal height on your home row.
descriptions.tafl: A collection of games from the Viking era. The defenders goal is to escape to the edge of the board, while the attackers try to capture the defender's king.
descriptions.tintas: Players race to either collect all seven of one colour or to collect four of four different colours.
descriptions.toguz: A traditional mancala-style sowing game from central Asia where you attempt to capture the majority of the pieces.
descriptions.trike: Trike is a game on a triangular board. Players take turn moving a neutral pawn around the board (passing is not allowed). When a player moves the pawn, they place a checker of their own color, onto the destination point. When the pawn is trapped, the game is over. At the end of the game, each player gets a point for each checker of their own color adjacent to, or underneath, the pawn. The person with the highest score wins.
descriptions.tumbleweed: Tumbleweed is a game of line of sight. Towers are built, and cells are controlled by the player with the most towers that can see that cell. Compete to control the majority of the hexagonal board.
descriptions.twixt: Twixt is a connection game where players alternate turns placing pegs and links on a pegboard in an attempt to link their opposite sides.
descriptions.urbino: In Urbino, one manipulates architects (like in the game Fabrik) to build districts of different building types according to a handful of placement rules. When no more moves are possible, districts are scored, and the highest score wins. Also includes the "Monuments" variant.
descriptions.valley: Get your king to the center space, but your pieces must always move as far as they can. Teamwork is essential.
descriptions.veletas: Veletas is a drawless territory game for two players. Both players control a number of neutral shooters and shoot stones of their own colour from them. In order to win, a player must claim a majority of neutral pieces by having them surrounded by larger groups of their own pieces than their opponent's.
descriptions.verge: Verge is a game where players attempt to create groups that partition the board, freezing those groups and removing enemy groups. The first player to have no legal placement wins.
descriptions.volcano: An Icehouse puzzle game for 2 players. Stacks of pyramids are volcanos, some of which are capped. As you move caps around, you cause eruptions that may lead to you capturing pieces. The winner is the first to capture a certain number of trios.
descriptions.witch: Four types of pieces are arrayed randomly on a grid. Each player takes turns removing pieces until one reaches a score of 50.
descriptions.wyke: A two-player game where one plays the builder and the other the destroyer. Claim cells by either completing or completely destroying lots. Win a certain number of lots or lots in a particular pattern to win.
descriptions.zola: A game where your movement is constrained by your distance from the centre of the board. Capturing moves must not increase that distance. Non-capturing moves must increase that distance. First person to capture all opposing pieces wins.

notes.armadas:
There are known issues with this game on iOS devices.

This game offers two scenarios:

* The default is each player having two trios of pieces. In the placement phase, each player must place 1 to 3 ships until all ships are placed.
* The "Freeform" variant allows you to place whatever ships you want (maximum of three at a time) until both players "pass." This lets you create unbalanced or otherwise asymmetrical fleets.

Games default to having one island in the centre of the field. Both a "no islands" and a "two islands" variant are available. You cannot move or fire through islands. To successfully hit a ship, at least one corner of your ship's triangle must have a clear view of at least one corner of the target ship.

Remember that it is possible to get your ship in a position against an island or the edge of the board such that you can no longer move that ship! Be careful!
notes.bao: Moves in Bao can be very complex, involving multiple laps around the board and changing directions. The annotations are, therefore, sparse. The initial cell and direction are higlighted, and captured cells are also marked. But detailed annotation of movement is not possible. If you believe you have encountered a bug, please let us know in Discord.
notes.binar: In the partisan variant, player 2 plays vertically. Rows are read from left to right. Columns are read from top to bottom. Moves are noted solely by row or column letter. Decimal values of the rows are given on the right. In the partisan variant, column values are given along the top.
notes.blooms: The threshold value is X(n) = 5n, where n is the base of the hexhex board (e.g., the default board is base 6, so the threshold is 30).
notes.chase: Currently, most exchange moves will need to be hand edited. We're working on fixing this.
notes.entropy: In this implementation, the players play two games simultaneously but with a single shared stream of randomized pieces. Each player places a piece on their *opponent's* Order board and then makes a move on their *own* Order board; players thus act as both Order and Chaos at the same time. The player with the greatest score wins! Since both players had the exact same placement choices, this provides the cleanest measure of relative skill.
notes.exxit: Because the board is built out as you play in irregular shapes, the hexes are labelled numerically instead of algebraically. We chose this so that the labels wouldn't change as the map grew. Because the labels aren't particularly helpful while you play, they are not displayed on the board. Also, translations of the rules tend to omit certain nuances. This implementation conforms with the original French edition of the rules.
notes.garden:
To make it very clear what happened on a previous turn, each move is displayed over four separate boards. The first board shows the game after the piece was first placed. The second board shows the state after adjacent pieces were flipped. The third board shows any harvests. The fourth board is the final game state and is where you make your moves.

In our implementation, black is always the "tome" or tie-breaker colour. The last player to harvest black will have a `0.1` after their score.
notes.homeworlds: The win condition is what's called "Sinister Homeworlds." You only win by defeating the opponent to your left. If someone else does that, the game continues, but your left-hand opponent now shifts clockwise. For example, in a four-player game, if I'm South, then I win if I eliminate West. But if the North player ends up eliminating West, the game continues, but now my left-hand opponent is North.
notes.loa: In the centre of the 9x9 board is a "black hole.". Landing on the black hole means the piece is removed from the game. Simultaneous connections are scored as a draw.
notes.mchess: If there have been seven consecutive turns without a capture, someone can "call the clock" by adding an asterisk (*) to the end of their move. This can only be done by selecting the move from the drop-down list. After another seven turns with no capture, the game will end and be scored.
notes.murus:
The default ruleset is "Advanced Murus Gallicus" (with catapults). By default, your first move is to redistribute one of your starting towers as walls on your second row. Additionally, the standard pie rule is also available. There are three variants you can mix and match:

* "Basic" reverts the game to the "no catapult" state.
* "Static" disables the initial tower redistribution.
* "Escape" eliminates the breakthrough win condition.
notes.pigs:
Unlike the old Super Duper Games implementation, this one implements the core rule set. Each player enters all five moves, and they are resolved at once.

Movement is resolved before damage is applied.
notes.queensland: After the first game completes, the board resets and you play a second game but with blue playing first. Highest combined score wins.
notes.razzle: The implementation here is the so called tournament rules.
notes.tablero:
When it's your turn, you will see the dice you have to work with, but once your move is complete, the dice will reroll. Exploration is not helpful because the dice roll is not finalized until after the move is submitted. As you scroll back through the game history, the dice you see are the dice for the *next* turn. The dice used to make the move you're seeing are displayed below the board.

While most moves can be unambiguously made by simple clicks, sometimes a button is more helpful. The Place, Take, and Bump buttons to the left of the board are there if you need them.
notes.tafl: The variant names are in the format {ruleset}-{board size}-{initial layout}-{optional: starting player}. For example, 'linnaean-9x9-tcross-w' is the linnaean rules on a 9x9 board with T-cross setup, and the starting player is the defenders. If starting player is not mentioned, then attackers start.
notes.taiji: Moves are done with two clicks. The first tile you place is always the light one, and then the dark one.
notes.tumbleweed: A space is claimed by a player if they have a piece on it, or if they have the majority of the line of sights to it. The score is the number of territory own by each player. The game ends when both players pass in succession. If there is no change in score for 20 plies, the game also ends.
notes.tbt: When it's your turn, you will see the die you have to work with, but once your move is complete, the die will reroll. Exploration is not helpful because the die roll is not finalized until after the move is submitted. As you scroll back through the game history, the die you see is for the *next* turn. The die used to make the move you're seeing is displayed below the board.
notes.toguz: Depicting state changes in sowing games is challenging. The initial chosen pit is marked, as is any capture. Small numbers appear to show the change in the number of stones in each pit. If you believe you have encountered a bug, please let us know in Discord.
notes.twixt: The notation is based on Hansel notation at <http://www.ibiblio.org/twixtpuzzles/>. Some modifications are that link removal specifically specifies the link direction, and commas separate the moves. To add/remove links, click on the pegs between them. You can also remove a link by clicking on the line itself.
notes.witch: The first player does not start as owning any pieces and may remove any piece (other than a crown) on their first turn. The second player chooses their colour on their first turn, after which, removing your opponent's pieces is no longer possible.

This creates what's called a "microverse," and it is not recommended for new players. If you're sure you want to do this, resubmit the command and put an asterisk (*) at the end of it.
homeworlds.CMD_HOME_RHO_SMALL: You are choosing to put yourself only two jumps away from your right-hand opponent (what's called a "small" universe), but it's possible for you to create a "large" universe (putting your right-hand opponent at the maximum three jumps away) if you choose one of your opponent's star sizes and the size their homeworld does *not* include. For new players, starting with a large universe is recommended. If you're sure you want a small universe, resubmit the command and put an asterisk (*) at the end of it.
homeworlds.CMD_HOME_SINGLE: You're requesting a home world with only one star. This puts you at a strong disadvantage. If you're sure you want to do this, resubmit the command and put an asterisk (*) at the end of it.

nex.PARTIAL_SWAP_ONE_EACH: Select one more neutral piece to swap to your colour, and one of your pieces to swap to the neutral colour.
nex.PARTIAL_SWAP_ONE_NEUTRAL: Select one more neutral piece to swap to your colour.
nex.PARTIAL_SWAP_ONE_PLAYER: Select one of your pieces to swap to the neutral colour.

nex.SWAP_EDGE_CASE_NOT_NEUTRAL: There is only one neutral piece and no more empty cells. You may not swap a piece of your colour to a neutral piece. Just swap the neutral piece to your colour.

ordo.DISCONNECTED: That move would leave your pieces disconnected.

pigs.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Enter 'R' to spend your whole turn repairing, or type five of the following characters: ^ (forward), v (backward), \ (forward left), / (forward right), < (turn left), > (turn right), F (fire laser), H (hit with snout), X (when damaged)

pigs.X_TOOFEW: You must enter an 'X' for every point of damage taken.

twixt.TOO_MANY_PEGS: You may only place one peg per turn.
twixt.CROSSING: The link at {{link}} is making an illegal cross.
twixt.PARTIAL_EMPTY: Trying to begin a partial move at an empty space {{move}}.
twixt.PARTIAL_OPPONENT: You may not rearrange your opponent's links.
twixt.PARTIAL_LINK: Select another peg to add or remove a link to.
twixt.CORNER: You may not place a peg at the corner of the board.
twixt.OPPONENTS_AREA: You may not place a peg in your opponent's area.

tumbleweed.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS_SETUP: Setup phase: place a piece of each colour on the board.
tumbleweed.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS_PASS: Either invoke the pie rule to play as first player or pass to play as second. If pie was already invoked, your only option is to pass.
tumbleweed.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Place a piece on the board.
tumbleweed.SECOND_PLAYER_PASS: Either invoke the pie rule to play as first player or pass to play as second. If pie was already invoked, your only option is to pass.
tumbleweed.TOO_MANY_MOVES: You may only make one move per turn, or two at in the setup phase as first player.
tumbleweed.NO_CENTRE: You may not place a piece at the centre of the board in the setup phase.
tumbleweed.SAME_CELL: In the setup phase, place two pieces on different cells.
tumbleweed.ONE_MORE: Place a piece of the other colour.
tumbleweed.INSUFFICIENT_LOS: There is insufficient line of sight to place a piece on {{cell}}.

urbino.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS_first: Select a cell in sight to place a piece, or you may pass if your opponent just placed the second architect.
urbino.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS_fresh: Place an architect in an empty cell.
urbino.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS_inprogress: Select an architect to move or select the size of a piece to place.
urbino.INVALID_PASS: You may only pass if you have no other moves available.
urbino.INVALID_PLACE_CELL: The cell {{where}} is not visible to both architects.

INVALID_PLACE_PIECE.house: You may not place a house here because it would create multiple blocks of one colour.
INVALID_PLACE_PIECE.palace: You may not place a palace here either because there is a palace adjacent or it would create multiple blocks of one colour.
INVALID_PLACE_PIECE.tower: You may not place a tower here either because there is a tower adjacent or it would create multiple blocks of one colour.

urbino.MUST_PASS_PLAY: The first turn after the second worker has been placed must be a pass or placement.
urbino.NOPLACEMENTS: You cannot move the workers such that you have no valid placements available.
urbino.PARTIAL_PLACE: Choose a cell to place a piece in.
urbino.PARTIAL_PLACE_SIZE: Select the size of a piece to place.

valley.KING_ONLY: Only the king may end its turn on the centre space.
valley.NO_STOPPING: Pieces must move in their chosen direction until stopped by the edge of the board or another piece.
valley.PAWN_FIRST: The first move of the game cannot be made with the king.

veletas.NO_MOVELIST: Move list not available during placement phase. Click on the board to place the shooters.
veletas.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Select a shooter to move or select a cell to place your piece.
veletas.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS_PLACE_one: Place {{count}} more shooter an empty space on the board, then place a piece of your colour on the board.
veletas.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS_PLACE_other: Place {{count}} more shooters on empty spaces on the board, then place a piece of your colour on the board.
veletas.SORTED: The move list needs to be sorted. Try {{normalised}}.
veletas.PLACE_SHOOTER_one: Place {{count}} more shooter on the board, then place a piece of your colour on the board.
veletas.PLACE_SHOOTER_other: Place {{count}} more shooters on the board, then place a piece of your colour on the board.
veletas.PLACE_PIECE: Place a piece of your colour on the board.
veletas.SHOOTER_PERIMETER: Shooters may not be placed on the perimeter of the board.
veletas.DUPLICATE: You have already placed a shooter at {{where}}.
veletas.STATIONARY_LOS: There is no line of sight to place at {{where}}.
veletas.INVALID_PLACEMENT: Unable to interpret the move notation: {{move}}.
veletas.MOVE_NON_SHOOTER: You may only move free shooters.
veletas.POTENTIAL_MOVE: So far so good. Provide the space you want to move the shooter to.
veletas.STRAIGHTLINE: You can only move and place in straight lines.
veletas.POTENTIAL_BLOCK: So far so good. Provide the space you want to place your piece at.

verge.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Select an empty cell that is not adjacent to one of your frozen groups.
verge.FROZEN_NEIGHBOUR: You cannot place next one of your frozen groups.

volcano.BAD_FROM: {{from}} doesn't look like a position on the board, or a piece in your stash.
volcano.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Select a cap to move or a piece from your captured pile to place on the board.
volcano.MOVES_AFTER_ERUPTION: You may not continue moving after causing an eruption.
volcano.MOVES_DOUBLE_CAP: Nothing may be placed on top of a cap.
volcano.MOVES_MUST_ERUPT: You must continue moving until you cause an eruption.
volcano.MOVES_NOPIECE: You don't have a {{piece}} piece in your stash to place.
volcano.MOVES_ONE_POWERPLAY: You may only make one power play per turn.
volcano.MOVES_ONE_SPACE: Caps may only be moved one space at a time.
volcano.PARTIAL_ERUPTION: Keep moving caps until you cause an eruption.

witch.2P_PRIVILEGE: Only the second player may choose the pieces they wish to play.
witch.AFFILIATE: Choose which piece you wish to play by clicking any sun or moon piece.
witch.BOTH_EMPTY: When selecting a line of pieces, both the start and end cells must be empty.
witch.EMPTY_CAPTURE: Captures must include at least one piece.
witch.INCOMPLETE_AFFILIATION: To choose your affliation, the move must start with '(S)' or '(M)'.
witch.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Click a piece to remove or an empty space to start removing a line of pieces.
witch.NO_CROWNS: You may not pick up crowns directly.
witch.NO_ENEMY: You may not pick up your opponent's pieces.
witch.ORTHOGONAL: Lines of pieces must be horizontal or vertical, never diagonal.
witch.PARTIAL: Select another empty space to remove the pieces in between.
witch.UNBROKEN: Lines of pieces must be unbroken by empty cells.

wyke.CELL_CLAIMED: The cell {{cell}} has already been claimed and cannot be interacted with further.
wyke.DUPLICATE_CELLS: You can't select the same cell multiple times.
wyke.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Select an available move from the button bar.
wyke.INVALID_FORMAT: Your move is in an invalid format: "{{move}}". It should start with the move type followed by a list of cells in parentheses (e.g., "3-1 (a1,b2)").
wyke.INVALID_MOVETYPE: The move "{{move}}" is not one of the five allowed movement types.
wyke.MOVETYPE_UNAVAILABLE: That move type is unavailable. Only select moves that are not stricken through.
wyke.PARTIAL: Continue selecting cells until the move is complete.
wyke.TOO_FEW_PIECES: There are too few pieces at {{where}} to remove {{num}} of them.
wyke.TOO_MANY_CELLS: You have selected more cells than the move type allows.
wyke.TOO_MANY_PIECES: There are too many pieces at {{where}} to add {{num}} more.

zola.DISTANCE_CAPTURES: Capture moves must not increase your distance from the centre.
zola.DISTANCE_NONCAPTURES: Non-capture moves must increase your distance from the centre.
zola.INITIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Select one of your own pieces.
zola.MUST_MOVE: If you have a move available you can not pass your turn.
zola.NONCAPTURES_KINGS: Non-capturing moves can only move one space at a time.

setup.description: Queens of each colour are on opposite halves of the board.

wall-placement.name: mandatory wall
wall-placement.description: You must place a wall after moving your piece if you have any in your stash.

goal.name: opponent's starting space goal
goal.description: You win by moving one of your pieces to a starting space of one of your opponent's pieces. Every piece must be able to reach EVERY goal square.

step-count.name: double-step
step-count.description: Pieces move two spaces orthogonally or one space diagonally, unless they are adjacent to a goal space, in which case they may move one space orthogonally to the goal. Any opponent piece on the goal will be captured on the winning move.

opening.name: centre opening
opening.description: The first stone has to be at the centre.

setup.description: Starts with a "cross" of two tiles of each colour.

placement.name: gravity downwards.
placement.description: Pieces must always be placed such that they're supported by at least one piece from below.

opening.name: pro opening
opening.description: The first player has to place their first stone in the centre of the board, and their second stone at least three intersections away from the centre.

ruleset.name: Halfcut ruleset
ruleset.description: Captures can only be made if the piece placed is larger than at least one opposing group in a crosscut.

board.name: board (9x9)
board.description: The default game is the 9x9 "black hole" variant. This will change eventually.

opening.name: pro opening
opening.description: The first player has to place their first stone in the centre of the board, and their second stone at least three intersections away from the centre.

overline.name: overline allowed
overline.description: You can win by forming a line of five or more stones

capture.name: capture rules
capture.description: You may only capture exactly 2 stones in each line.

self-capture.name: self-capture ignored
self-capture.description: Players may place a stone in a formation where it is surrounded by opponent's pieces such that it would ordinarily result in a capture without consequences.

overtime-capture.name: no overtime capture
overtime-capture.description: The game ends immediately when a player makes a winning alignment.

setup.name: setup
setup.description: The starting position will be an empty board.

opening.name: centre opening
opening.description: The first player has to place their first stone in the centre of the board. There are no other opening placement restrictions.

ruleset.name: rules
ruleset.description: A swap must decrease either the number of crosscuts or the number of supercuts on the board, and it must not increase the number of crosscuts.

penalty.name: penalty (-8)
penalty.description: A lower penalty creates a more aggressive game, and a higher penalty, a more conservative one.

variant.name: linnaean-9x9-tcross-w
variant.description: Linnaean Sámi Tablut with historical rules based on a recent reconstruction from Linnaeus' diary. It is an edge escape variant with an armed king that is strong on the throne and on the four squares adjacent to the throne, but weak everywhere else.

rules.name: rules
rules.description: Play on a size 5 board where plant growth destroys dirt.

ruleset.name: ruleset
ruleset.description: Links cannot cross. You may rearrange your links before you place your peg.

setup.name: freestyle setup
setup.description: The first player places shooters and a stone of their colour, then the second player chooses if they want to invoke the pie rule. After that the second player places more shooters and a stone, and the game begins.

snub.description: A hybrid orthogonal/hexagonal board shape with unique connection characteristics.
snub.name: Board: Snub Square

pari.description: Instead of having individual piece types, pieces move depending on how many friendly pieces are in the stack. The top piece of a stack with three of your pieces will move like a chariot, two pieces like a horse, and one piece like a shield.
pari.name: Accasta Pari

cobweb.name: Cobweb (4 rings)
cobweb.description: A variant played on a round board where you try to connect two opposite sides.

cobweb-small.name: Cobweb (3 rings)
cobweb-small.description: A smaller Cobweb board where the centre becomes more important.

standard-11.name: Triangle (11 wide)
standard-11.description: A larger version of the standard board.

standard-14.name: Triangle (14 wide)
standard-14.description: A larger version of the standard board.

advanced.description: Makes it harder for the defenders by allowing invaders to stack on top of a king on an exit space. Defender wins if they *start* their turn with the king on an escape spot.
advanced.name: Advanced

cross.name: Cross
cross.description: Queens of the same colour are situated across from each other.

scrambled.name: Scrambled
scrambled.description: Queens alternate colour around the board.

8x10.description: An elongated board that breaks up the power of a central diagonal
8x10.name: 8x10 board

freeform.description: Lets the players determine their own fleet compositions. Requires good communication before starting.
freeform.name: Freeform

grand.description: Played on a larger board, with more voids, and the goal now is to create five triple stacks.
grand.name: Grand Attangle

kujifunza.description: The "beginner" version with no "kunamua" setup phase. The game starts with two stones in each pit.
kujifunza.name: Bao la kujifunza

malawi.description: The house starts with 8 stones instead of 6.
malawi.name: Malawi

partisan.name: Partisan Variant
partisan.description: Player 1 increments rows and player 2 increments columns. Victory condition is the same.

optional-wall.name: Optional wall
optional-wall.description: After making a move with one of your pieces, the placement of the wall is optional.

exclusive-wall.name: Exclusive wall
exclusive-wall.description: On your turn, you may either move a piece or place a wall, but not both.

back-rank.name: Opponent's back-rank goal
back-rank.description: You win by moving one of your pieces to the opponent's back rank. Every piece must be able to reach at least one goal square.

single-step.name: Single-step
single-step.description: Pieces move one step orthogonally. If there is an opponent's piece in the way, they may jump over it unless it is the on the goal space, in which case it would just land on the goal, capturing the opponent's piece. In the unlikely event where another opponent's piece is behind the piece to be jumped, that piece is captured.

bombardment.description: Instead of regular capture moves, you can detonate a piece, which destroys it and any pieces immediately surrounding it.
bombardment.name: Bombardment

snub.description: A hybrid orthogonal/hexagonal board shape with unique connection characteristics.
snub.name: Board: Snub Square

swap-3rd.name: Swap-3rd opening
swap-3rd.description: The first player places one stone of their colour in the centre, then the second places two stones of their colour in the centre 5x5, and finally the first player places two stones of their colour anywhere on the board. The second player has the option to swap colours.

pass.name: Pass tiebreak
pass.description: After the opening phase, a player may pass instead of make a move to win the tiebreaker. If the board is filled without a winner, the player who passed wins. If no player passed, then the second player wins.

topBottom.name: Above/Below
topBottom.description: Players own the rows closest to them (as in most mancala games)rather than the left half of the board.

stones.description: In this variant, the players place three impassable stones in the middle of the board.
stones.name: Stumbling Blocks

29tiles.description: If you just want a shorter game
29tiles.name: Shorter game (29 tiles)

exNihilo.description: Starts with an empty field, and the first three turns are placing tiles
exNihilo.name: Ex Nihilo

arbeiter.description: Each player controls one worker and cannot move the other. The victory condition is comensurately reduced to three pieces in a row instead of four.
arbeiter.name: Arbeiter

simplified.name: Learning game
simplified.description: You only play with three pieces of each colour, and the grid is constrained to 7x7 instead of 9x9.

swap-2.name: Swap-2 opening
swap-2.description: The first player places three pieces. The second player may do one of (1) place a single pieces to continue as player 2, (2) swap colours to play as player 1, or (3) place two more pieces and allow the opponent to decide to play as player 1 or player 2.

swap-5.name: Swap-5 opening
swap-5.description: For the first five pieces on the board, after placement, the next player has the option to swap colours.

edge-grow-4.name: Edge-grow-4
edge-grow-4.description: Pieces "grow" from the edges: you may place on any first free space from any edge.

edge-drop-4.name: Edge-drop-4
edge-drop-4.description: Pieces "drop" from the edges: you may place on a free space right before the first filled space from any edge. Edges cannot be blocked, so the pieces are actually dropped from the first free space from the edge.

interior-gravity-4.name: Interior gravity-4
interior-gravity-4.description: Pieces appear from any free space on the board, then slide to the free space right before the first filled space in the direction of the closest edge. On the diagonal where it is equidistant to two edges, the piece will slide to the closest corner.

clear.name: Clear
clear.description: If a row at the edge is entirely filled with pieces, it is cleared, and all pieces shift in that direction. A four-in-a-row takes priority over a shift. When used with the 4-directional variants, the board will shift in any direction(s) where there are full rows. Note that this can result in board configurations that are not normally feasible, but it is a predictable behaviour.

swap-2.name: Swap-2 opening
swap-2.description: The first player places three stones. The second player may do one of (1) place a single stone to continue as player 2, (2) swap colours to play as player 1, or (3) place two more stones and allow the opponent to decide to play as player 1 or player 2.

swap-5.name: Swap-5 opening
swap-5.description: For the first five stones on the board, after placement, the next player has the option to swap colours.

pass.name: Pass tiebreak
pass.description: After the opening phase, a player may pass instead of make a move to win the tiebreaker. If the board is filled without a winner, the player who passed wins. If no player passed, second player wins.

clearcut.name: Clearcut ruleset
clearcut.description: Captures can only be made if the piece placed is larger than at both opposing groups in a crosscut. Full rulesheet: <https://www.marksteeregames.com/Clearcut_rules.pdf>

swap-2.name: Swap-2 opening
swap-2.description: The first player places three stones. The second player may do one of (1) place a single stone to continue as player 2, (2) swap colours to play as player 1, or (3) place two more stones and allow the opponent to decide to play as player 1 or player 2.

swap-5.name: Swap-5 opening
swap-5.description: For the first five stones on the board, after placement, the next player has the option to swap colours.

pass.name: Pass tiebreak
pass.description: After the opening phase, a player may pass instead of make a move to win the tiebreaker. If the board is filled without a winner, the player who passed wins. If no player passed, then the second player wins.

scrambled.description: Pieces are interspersed with each other instead of starting together on opposite sides of the board.
scrambled.name: Scrambled Eggs

freestyle.description: Players take turn placing their miners on the board. When all miners are placed, player 2 starts.
freestyle.name: Freestyle placement

ofkk.description: Pawns move like Chess kings, and drones move like Chess knights.
ofkk.name: Of Knights and Kings

three.description: The winner is the first to score two points.
three.name: Best of Three

five.description: The winner is the first to score three points.
five.name: Best of Five

basic.description: Only walls and towers can be built (maximum stack size is 2).
basic.name: Basic MG

escape.description: The winning condition is to stalemate your opponent. Breaking through is not sufficient.
escape.name: Escape

static.description: No initial redistribution of a starting tower.
static.name: Static Start

noglobes.description: Neither player starts with any globes.
noglobes.name: No Starting Globes

swap-2.name: Swap-2 opening
swap-2.description: The first player places three stones. The second player may do one of (1) place a single stone to continue as player 2, (2) swap colours to play as player 1, or (3) place two more stones and allow the opponent to decide to play as player 1 or player 2.

swap-5.name: Swap-5 opening
swap-5.description: For the first five stones on the board, after placement, the next player has the option to swap colours.

overline-ignored.name: Overline ignored
overline-ignored.description: Overline moves are legal, but they do not count as a win. It's possible to capture a stone such that your opponent wins. Draws are possible if both players simultaneously meet the win condition.

overline-forbidden.name: Overline forbidden
overline-forbidden.description: Any move that would create a line of six or more stones is illegal.

capture-2-3.name: Capture 2-3 (Keryo Pente)
capture-2-3.description: You may capture 2 or 3 stones in a line.

self-capture.name: Self-capture allowed (Poof Pente)
self-capture.description: When players place a stone in a formation where it is surrounded by opponent's pieces such that it would ordinarily result in a capture, those stones are removed as though the opponent captured them. All captures are determined before any removal is made. This means that if we initially had XO_XXO, and the O player places at the empty space, it results in X____O, and each player gains two points.

self-capture-forbidden.name: Self-capture forbidden
self-capture-forbidden.description: Players may not place their stones in a formation where it is surrounded by opponent's pieces such that it would ordinarily result in a capture.

overtime-capture.name: Overtime capture (Boat Pente)
overtime-capture.description: When a player makes a winning alignment, the opponent has one move to try to break that alignment.

15pts.description: The game doesn't end until you have 15 points worth of enemy soldiers.
15pts.name: Longer Game: 15 points

random.name: Random setup
random.description: The starting position will have some pre-flooded spaces.

capturedBases.name: Tie break: Captured bases
capturedBases.description: The number of captured bases becomes a second tie breaker.

checkpoint.name: Checkpoint Charley
checkpoint.description: Moving pieces must stop in the first enemy controlled realm they enter.

control.name: Control freak
control.description: When rearranging a realm, you may also rearrange your opponent's pieces.

lastFirst.name: And the last shall be first
lastFirst.description: After initial base and power placement, the second player moves first.

relaxed.name: Relaxed placement
relaxed.description: There are no restrictions on initial base placement.

replacement.name: Capture by replacement
replacement.description: Captured bases are immediately replaced by one of your own. Leads to a much faster game.

taraguchi-10.name: Taraguchi-10 opening
taraguchi-10.description: Beginner-friendly rule that is popular in correspondence games. Each player places one stone during the opening and the other player may swap. 10-tentative-fifths rule is implemented in case a player tries to make an exploitive opening (beginners may ignore this). <https://www.renju.net/rule/25/>

soosyrv-8.name: Soosõrv-8 opening
soosyrv-8.description: Official tournament rule since 2015. Starts like RIF, but upon placing the fourth stone, up to 8 tentative fifths can be declared, and the other player may swap. <https://www.renju.net/rule/24/>

yamaguchi.name: Yamaguchi opening
yamaguchi.description: Official tournament rule from 2009 to 2015. Simple modification to the RIF opening where instead of a fixed number of tentative fifths (two), on the first move, the player declares the number of tentative fifths. <https://www.renju.net/rule/5/>

rif.name: Classic RIF opening
rif.description: Classic Renju International Federation rules. Select a canonical opening and the other player may swap. Two tentative fifths are given. <https://www.renju.net/rule/1/>

swap-2.name: Swap-2 opening
swap-2.description: Free opening. The first player places three stones. The second player may do one of (1) place a single stone to continue as player 2, (2) swap colours to play as player 1, or (3) place two more stones and allow the opponent to decide to play as player 1 or player 2.

swap-5.name: Swap-5 opening
swap-5.description: Free opening. For the first five stones on the board, after placement, the next player has the option to swap colours.

pass.name: Pass tiebreak
pass.description: After the opening phase, a player may pass instead of make a move to win the tiebreaker. If the board is filled without a winner, the player who passed wins. If no player passed, second player wins.

octagon-8.name: Octagonal board (8x8)
octagon-8.description: Standard 8x8 board with the corners blocked.

octagon-10.name: Octagonal board (10x10)
octagon-10.description: Standard 10x10 board with the corners blocked.

hexagon-5.name: Hexagonal board (base-5)
hexagon-5.description: Hexagonal base-5 board with setup popularised by ItsYourTurn.com.

hexagon-6.name: Hexagonal board (base-6)
hexagon-6.description: Hexagonal base-6 board with setup popularised by ItsYourTurn.com.

anti.name: Anti-Reversi
anti.description: The player who has the fewest pieces at the end of the game wins.

basic.name: Basic rules
basic.description: A swap must decrease the number of crosscuts. Draws are possible.

5point.name: Lower penalty (-5)
5point.description: The lower penalty makes it easier to steal enemy territory with a new line, leading to a more aggressive game.

15point.name: Higher penalty (-15)
15point.description: The higher penalty makes invading enemy territory more expensive, leading to a euro-style game that focuses on building.

linnaean-11x11-belldiamond-w.name: linnaean-11x11-belldiamond-w
linnaean-11x11-belldiamond-w.description: Bell-diamond setup with historical rules based on a recent reconstruction from Linnaeus' diary. It is an edge escape variant with an armed king that is strong on the throne and on the four squares adjacent to the throne, but weak everywhere else.

linnaean-11x11-lewiscross-w.name: linnaean-11x11-lewiscross-w
linnaean-11x11-lewiscross-w.description: Lewis-cross setup with historical rules based on a recent reconstruction from Linnaeus' diary. It is an edge escape variant with an armed king that is strong on the throne and on the four squares adjacent to the throne, but weak everywhere else.

copenhagen-11x11-tdiamond.name: copenhagen-11x11-tdiamond
copenhagen-11x11-tdiamond.description: Popular Hnefatafl variant based on the Fetlar rules with strong armed king and corner escape rules. Has shield wall captures and exit forts.

berserk-11x11-tdiamondberserk.name: berserk-11x11-tdiamondberserk
berserk-11x11-tdiamondberserk.description: Berserk variant of the Fetlar rules with knights and commanders. Multi-step captures are permitted, and the king may escape to the corner immediately after a capture.

total-11x11-tdiamond.name: total-11x11-tdiamond
total-11x11-tdiamond.description: A combination of Fetlar, Copenhagen and Berserk rules. It is a strong armed king with corner escape rules, with shield wall captures, exit forts, and encirclement win. Berserk capture is enabled and the king can make a berserk escape. Repetitions result in a draw.

tyr-11x11-tyr.name: tyr-11x11-tyr
tyr-11x11-tyr.description: Berserk rules with weak armed king and edge escape on a 11x11 board. This is the default simple Tyr setup without special pieces.

tyr-15x15-tyr.name: tyr-15x15-tyr
tyr-15x15-tyr.description: Berserk rules with weak armed king and edge escape on a 15x15 board. This is the default simple Tyr setup without special pieces.

seabattle-9x9-starsquare-w.name: seabattle-9x9-starsquare-w
seabattle-9x9-starsquare-w.description: Strong unarmed king and edge escape on a 9x9 board.

seabattle-11x11-tcross-w.name: seabattle-11x11-tcross-w
seabattle-11x11-tcross-w.description: Strong unarmed king and edge escape on a 11x11 board.

magpie-7x7-cross.name: magpie-7x7-cross
magpie-7x7-cross.description: A Hnefatafl variant from the book The Leprechaun Companion by Nigel Suckling. It has a strong armed King that only moves one space. The king can be captured on the edges.

squares.name: Sum of Squares
squares.description: Adds together the square of each of your n largest groups.

products.name: Product
products.description: Multiplies together the sizes of your n largest groups.

high-churn.name: High Churn
high-churn.description: Play on a size 4 board where plant growth does not destroy dirt.

quick-churn.name: Small, High Churn
quick-churn.description: Play on a size 3 board where plant growth does not destroy dirt.

pp.name: Paper and pencil
pp.description: Players' own links are allowed to cross each other. There are no link rearrangements.

monuments.description: Monuments are combinations of specific pieces in a row. Each district will score the most valuble monument present for each colour. Most valuable monument becomes the first tie breaker in districts, but not when breaking end-of-game ties.
monuments.name: Monuments

labyrinth.name: Labyrinth
labyrinth.description: Board size increases to 7x7 and four towers further complicate the field.

king-swap.name: Retrieve the King
king-swap.description: Kings start on the opposing side of the board.

random.name: Randomised setup
